prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Factors in Deciding Whether Transfer Is Appropriate

para.paratext: The Panel does not always treat all cases before it on a single docket the same way. The Panel can order partial transfer in certain circumstances, and has done so in order to advance the purposes of the statute. Partial transfer is authorized under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1407(a), which provides in part:
Provided, however, that the panel may separate any claim, crossclaim, counter-claim, or third-party claim and remand any of such claims before the remainder of the action is remanded.[1]

The most important facet of this statute is the specific authority to order remand only of an entire claim. The Panel cannot select certain issues for transfer for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and others for continued handling in the transferor courts, but it can decline to transfer individual actions despite ordering transfer of the remaining cases.[2] The Panel observed in an early case:

While paragraph (a) of Section 1407 permits separation and remand by the Panel of claims, cross-claims, counterclaims and third-party claims separable under paragraph (b) of Rule 42, it does not permit the Panel to order a separate trial of any separate issue or … issues which are also separable under paragraph (b) of Rule 42. This unequivocal and obviously deliberate withholding from the Panel of power to separate issues in a single civil action assigning one or more to the transferee court and one or more to the transferor court is a clear, precise and wise limitation on the powers of the Panel.[3]

Transfer of part of a case presents another issue that neither Congress nor the Panel has dealt with clearly. When part of a case is transferred and part remains pending in the transferee court, the entry of a final order in the transferee court is not clearly “final” for the purposes of appeal. Indeed, the Ninth Circuit confronted this issue and concluded that because the MDL transferee court's dismissal order did not resolve all of the claims against a party (other claims remained pending in the transferor court), it was not appealable in the absence of certification for entry of a partial final judgment pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 54(b).[4] The court remanded to the transferee court to determine whether the judgment should be made final and immediately appealable. The court noted that the Panel takes the step of separating claims in this matter in a “not insignificant number” of cases.[5]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
